Award.AwardTitle: Poising of RNA Polymerase II: Features and Functions

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. The initial discovery of the occupancy of RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) at certain genes prior to their transcriptional activation occurred over a quarter century ago in Drosophila. Due to recent advances in whole genome analyses, occupancy of RNAPII in an inactive state can be detected in organisms across the evolutionary spectrum and at diverse sets of genes. The goal of this project is to investigate post-recruitment mechanisms of gene regulation by focusing on poised RNAPII in yeast and the response to oxidative stress as the regulatory system. These studies take full advantage of the available approaches (genetics, molecular biology, biochemistry, cell biology, genomics), and are amenable to researchers at a variety of levels (graduate, undergraduate and elementary school students). Thus, the transcriptional response to oxidative stress will be investigated with a focus on the pre-bound and poised RNAPII complex by testing two overarching hypotheses: 1) Poised promoters share common features that are distinct from recruitment-regulated promoters; and 2) Poised promoters offer functional advantage(s) for the regulation of gene expression. Since post-recruitment regulation is widespread in humans and other organisms, these findings will significantly impact the field of gene expression with exceptional potential to alter our overall views. Thus, these studies are extremely timely and highly significant.

Broader Impacts. The project has broad impact in at least four ways. First, the studies offer suitable projects for undergraduate trainees, who may have time constraints as well as limited laboratory experience. Second, studies with higher technical and time demands provide outstanding cross-training experiences for graduate students in a number of different disciplines (genetics, genomics, cell and molecular biology). These techniques are highly versatile. Trainees will utilize these techniques in the future if they choose to investigate other critical genetic mechanisms (DNA repair, replication, recombination, RNA metabolism, epigenetics, etc.). Third, to propagate the tradition of outreach, undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in taking gene expression studies into elementary school classrooms. As part of a previously funded NSF project, fifth graders and their teachers helped to develop a novel outreach program called 'Biochemistry is Elementary'. This innovative program has eight separate 1 hour sessions involving hands-on activities designed to explore basic concepts of scientific reasoning involving biochemistry and yeast genetics. Due to the inexpensive and biologically safe reagents and the detailed workbooks created during the project, many scientists could offer something similar to their local community if they received training on the program. As such, this program will be expanded to include an interactive website. Finally, results from this project will be published in broad based scientific journals, and presented at local and international meetings. Taken together, this project directly supports the mission of the NSF to advance discovery and understanding, while promoting teaching, training and learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) is the enzyme responsible for expressing most protein-coding genes present in our DNA. The initial discovery of RNAPII bound at genes prior to their transcriptional activation and expression occurred over a quarter century ago in Drosophila. These "poised" complexes, present in an inactive state, are now apparent in many different organisms (yeast, flies, humans). DNA is packaged with histones to form a protective and compacted structure called chromatin. We characterized the poised S. cerevisiae CYC1 gene during the inactive to active transition, and found that many histone binding proteins and chromatin remodeling complexes are essential for this transition. Our studies also lead to our discovery of Spn1, a highly conserved chromatin factor with important roles in transcriptional elongation and chromatin architecture.

A number of conceptual innovations derived from this project (described in 4 publications). First, we developed a histone exchange assay, which is easily portable into any strain (Chen et al., 2016). This will be an outstanding tool to measure exchange of histones  in various mutant backgrounds to provide new information about the dynamic nature of chromatin during activation of transcription. Second, we utilized the power of the yeast system to undertake new genetic assays with the anticipated outcome of discovering new connections. Using this approach, we found that a protein originally identified as important for regulation of a poised promoter, also plays roles in the repair of DNA damage and yeast aging (Thurston et al., 2018). Third, we developed sophisticated binding assays for examining functions of histone binding proteins in vitro, which informed on the mechanism of action of these factors (Li et al., 2018, Mattiroli, et al., 2017). Our findings are highly significant since regulation of chromatin structure is integral to the spatial and temporal control of gene expression programs, which underlies the ability of cells to grow, differentiate, and respond to environmental and developmental cues.

 

Our project was designed to offer diverse training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in genetics, cell biology, and biochemistry. Importantly, a majority of these techniques are versatile, and prepared trainees to answer biological questions concerning other genetic mechanisms in their current careers. Most of the techniques (cloning, DNA amplification, cell culturing, genetic screens, protein and DNA binding assays) and projects were accessible to undergraduate students with lower training levels and time constraints. Thus, the work offered authentic training opportunities for researchers at a variety of skill levels.

 

This project offered opportunities for research training and professional development for 2 Ph.D. students (both of which are currently postdoctoral fellows), and 5 undergraduate students. Our outreach program ?Biochemistry is Elementary? (developed during previous support; see Ross et al., 2012) provided public engagement opportunities for 2 postdoctoral fellows, 30 graduate students, 6 undergraduate students, and 5 faculty members from a variety of departments at Colorado State University. In addition, ~700 fifth grade students and seven elementary school teachers participated in and helped develop scientific experiments in genetics and biochemistry. This program provided a positive environment for elementary school students to interact with professional scientists. We created 10 sessions involving hands-on activities designed to introduce genetics and biochemistry to fifth graders, with a capstone experience of 5th graders isolating their own DNA. Successful completion of this experiment required the students be on task, add multiple reagents in the correct sequence and delicately handle their DNA during isolation. Despite these challenges, 75% of the students chose this experiment as ?their favorite? in our post-program survey. Their enthusiastic response to this experiment is apparent in comments: ?DNA isolation was my favorite because we were able to make our own DNA necklaces with our own DNA?,  ?we were able to see our own DNA?, and ?I never in my life got to see my own coding system.? Due to the inexpensive and safe reagents and the custom workbooks we created in collaboration with our elementary school participants, many scientists could offer something similar in their local community. We hope that the involvement of young students with our project will cultivate a life-long interest in science while also introducing them to the potential for science as a career, concepts in genetics and biochemistry, and the value of studying model systems (an idea that has not always been effectively conveyed to the general public).

 

Taken together, the intellectual merit of our project provided outstanding training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and resulted in published discoveries that advanced our understanding of how chromatin structure is maintained during transcription by proteins conserved from yeast to humans. The broader impacts included a tremendously successful outreach program that involved graduate and undergraduate students at CSU, and engaged 5th grade teachers and their students, which we hope will serve to inspire our next generation of scientists and science educators.
